introduction.p:
This activity concerns a function f(x) about which the following information is known:
f is a differentiable function defined at every real number x
f(2) = -1
y = f'(x) has its graph given in Figure

figure.caption: At center, a graph of y = f'(x); at left, axes for plotting y = f(x); at right, axes for plotting y = f''(x).

introduction.p: Your task is to determine as much information as possible about f (especially near the value a = 2) by responding to the questions below.

statement.p: Find a formula for the tangent line approximation, L(x), to f at the point (2,-1).

hint.p: Find the value of f'(2) from the given graph of f.

solution.p: Since f(2) = -1 and f'(2) = 2, we have L(x) = -1 + 2(x-2).

statement.p: Use the tangent line approximation to estimate the value of f(2.07). Show your work carefully and clearly.
Sketch a graph of y = f''(x) on the righthand grid in Figure; label it appropriately.

hint.p: The graph of y = f''(x) is the derivative of the graph of y = f'(x).

statement.p: Is the slope of the tangent line to y = f(x) increasing, decreasing, or neither when x = 2? Explain.

hint.p: Is f' increasing, decreasing, or neither when x = 2?

solution.p: The slope of the tangent line to y = f(x) is increasing for x \lt 2 because y = f'(x) is an increasing function on this interval. Similarly, for x > 2, the slope of the tangent line to y = f(x) is decreasing. Right at x = 2, the slope of the tangent line to y = f(x) is neither increasing nor decreasing.

statement.p: Sketch a possible graph of y = f(x) near x = 2 on the lefthand grid in Figure. Include a sketch of y=L(x) (found in part (a)). Explain how you know the graph of y = f(x) looks like you have drawn it.

hint.p: Draw y = L(x) first. Then think about options for f relative to the graph of L.

See the plot in the image below, which shows, at left, a possible graph of y = f(x) near x = 2, along with the tangent line y = L(x) through (2, f(2)).
Note that y = f(x) is concave up for x \lt 2 since f' is increasing on that interval, and y = f(x) is concave down for x > 2 since f' is decreasing there. Hence y = f(x) changes from concave up to concave down right at x = 2, which is also the point near 2 where the graph of y = f(x) is steepest.

statement.p: Does your estimate in (b) over- or under-estimate the true value of f(2.07)? Why?

hint.p: Does the tangent line lie above or below the graph of y = f(x) at (2,3)?

solution.p: Because the tangent line to y = f(x) lies above the graph of f to the right of x = 2, our estimate of f(2.07) is too large the local linearization overshoots the true value of f at this point.
